metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Heirs and Legal Representatives of Amarchand N. Shroff

facts.text: Amarchand N. Shroff, Mangaldas and Hiralal were partners in a firm of solicitors.
Partnership carried on by Mangaldas and Hiralal up to November 30, 1949.
On December 1, 1949, Ramesh son of Amarchand joined the firm as the third partner.

Arrangement: realisations of old outstandings from work done up to death of Amarchand divided amongst Amarchand, Mangaldas and Hiralal; from July 8, 1949 to November 30, 1949 between Mangaldas and Hiralal; after December 1, 1949 amongst Mangaldas, Hiralal and Ramesh.
Firm kept accounts on cash basis.

For assessment years 1950-51 to 1954-55, amounts received by heirs and legal representatives of Amarchand: Rs. 37,847/- (1950-51), Rs. 43,162/- (1951-52), Rs. 34,899/- (1952-53), Rs. 13,402/- (1953-54), Rs. 32,523/- (1954-55).
Income-tax Officer sought to tax these realisations; for 1950-51 and 1951-52 assessed in hands of heirs as Hindu undivided family.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then Appellate Tribunal; Tribunal held amounts not income of HUF but inheritance or realisations of assets of Amarchand.
Revenue started proceedings u/s 34 in respect of same income in hands of Amarchand N. Shroff by his heirs as individual.
Assessments made u/s 34(b) read with s.24B for 1950-51 to 1954-55.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner held notice u/s 34 valid only for 1950-51; quashed for 1951-52 to 1954-55.
Tribunal held assessment could not be made on Amarchand; s.24B had no application to income received after death; capital receipt not revenue.
Reference to High Court: Whether sums assessable u/s 24B in hands of assessee Amarchand by legal heirs.
High Court answered negative; s.24B no application.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 37,847/-, Rs. 43,162/-, Rs. 34,899/-, Rs. 13,402/- and Rs. 32,523/- were assessable to income-tax in the hands of the assessee Amarchand N. Shroff by his legal heirs and representatives in the five respective years under reference?
Interpretation of s.24B of Income-tax Act: whether amounts received by heirs after death deemed income of deceased.

petitioner_arguments.text: On correct interpretation of s.24B, amounts received by heirs after death deemed by fiction in sub-s.(1) to be income received by Amarchand and liable to tax; heirs liable out of estate as deceased would have been if alive. Emphasis on 'or any tax which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had not died'.
Scheme of the Act supports taxing such receipts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Additional Income-tax Officer v. E. Alfred; B.M. Kamdar; Sreemati Usharani Shoudhurani

respondent_arguments.text: s.24B has no application to income received after death of Amarchand; capital receipt not revenue.

court_reasoning.text: s.24B(1) divided into two parts: tax assessed before death or tax payable if not died; read with sub-ss.(2),(3), confined to income received before death or by heirs in previous year of death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'if he had not died' restricted to previous year of death.

court_reasoning.text: s.24B extends legal personality of deceased only for previous year of death; income received subsequent years not assessable as his income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Firm on cash basis; assessee ordinarily living person.

court_reasoning.text: Fiction in s.24B limited to purpose; cannot extend beyond previous year. Precedents distinguished as they involved receipts in previous year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal fictions limited to purpose for which created.

holdings.text: s.24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by legal representatives in years succeeding previous year of death.
Amounts not liable to tax as income of deceased in hands of heirs.

precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of words 'if he had not died'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: No assessment after death without s.24B; lacuna filled by s.24B limited to previous year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Additional Income-tax Officer v. E. Alfred
precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of Act; nothing supports contention.
Assessee alive when received; s.24B inapplicable.
Amount received in previous year; earned during lifetime.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment on living person; charge on previous year income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Legal fictions limited to purpose created.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.24B interpreted: liability only for income up to previous year of death; proceedings u/s 34 with s.24B.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upheld High Court answering the reference in negative against Commissioner; amounts not assessable u/s 24B as income of deceased in hands of heirs.
outcome.relief_granted: None to petitioner; assessments not upheld.

key_quotes.text: "Section 24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of s.24B.

key_quotes.text: "By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits fiction to previous year of death.

key_quotes.text: "Legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should not be extended beyond that legitimate field."
key_quotes.speaker: court
